So she only went 'cause her kid, who is like totes gonna be a history major or something, would totally dig something like this. Like, if you were born years ago, you'd be at that age where they'd send dudes off to war. The mom said that while lighting up a cigarette. The kid totally knew this stuff (since he’s into history and all), but he just let his mom feel like she's the wise one here. He couldn't imagine being alive back then. It must've been insane. Was that even fair? She sighed. No way, it wasn't fair. Old politicians making young people do their dirty work—it’s so unfair, isn't it? The boy knew that history was full of stories where many people's sacrifices only helped a few, which is kinda how it rolls, or used to until things changed. Now, people live in like peace, not poverty. They roll in cash, not chaos. Sure, the news is filtered, and everything's tightly controlled, but it's small potatoes for saving so many lives, right? Turning to an old tank with a literal tree growing outta it, the boy noticed it was beat up—probably ate too many bullets but didn’t go down. The mom kept going, “I remember when I could switch channels and watch whatever I wanted. There were loads of news stations, Billy. All of them with different takes. Then sirens, and another shot, followed by a woman's cry. Democracy, the boy thought, is slow and costs a lot. But is this really the better option?
